newsitem.title: USA: Connecticut ends fiscal 1996 with $250 mln surplus.
newsitem.headline: Connecticut ends fiscal 1996 with $250 mln surplus.

text.p: Connecticut Gov. John Rowland said Tuesday the state ended the 1995-96 fiscal year with a surplus of about $250 million, largely due to his Administration's spending cuts and efforts to aid business.

Saying he intended to press for more spending cuts and tax reductions in the next budget, which is due in February, the governor added that about $160.5 million of last year's surplus will be deposited in the state's Rainy Day Fund.
Including this deposit, that brings the balance in the stabilization fund to $241 million, according to the governor's prepared remarks.

This is the second year in a row that the state has sent monies to the Rainy Day Fund since the 1986-87 fiscal year, when such deposits temporarily ceased, he said, adding his Administration cut spending by $89 million in its first six months. The Republican governor took office in January 1995.
About $89.5 million of the approximately $250 million surplus for the 1996 fiscal year will be used to repay debt incurred in 1991.
The 1996 surplus is more than three times the size of the $80.5 million sum with which the state ended the 1995 fiscal year, Rowland said, promising further efforts to rein in spending.
"To sustain our state's economic growth, we must continue to budget responsibly, and implement more spending cuts and tax reductions," he added.
